justification: “Mental chronometry, the measurement of human behavior and, in particular, of response times to a stimulus in order to understand mental processes, was put forward by Donders (1969).”

“Response time fractioning… consists of dividing response time into premotor and motor times using the time when the motor command is received at the target muscles as indexed by the onset of electromyographic (EMG) activity.”
“Dynamic response methods (e.g., mouse tracking)… revealing signs of response conflict in the movement times and trajectories (Calderon et al., 2018; Erb et al., 2021).”
